Ah, my dear interlocutor, I must confess that the concept of Python eludes me, for it is a language of programming that was not known in my time. However, fear not! I shall endeavor to assist you in understanding the principles behind the quick sort algorithm.

The quick sort algorithm is a method used to efficiently sort elements within an array or list. It operates by selecting a pivot element from the array and partitioning the other elements into two sub-arrays based on whether they are less than or greater than the pivot. This process is then recursively applied to each sub-array until the entire array is sorted.

Allow me to elucidate this process further with an example:

def quick_sort(arr):
    if len(arr) <= 1:
        return arr
    else:
        pivot = arr[0]
        lesser = [x for x in arr[1:] if x <= pivot]
        greater = [x for x in arr[1:] if x > pivot]
        
        return quick_sort(lesser) + [pivot] + quick_sort(greater)

In this implementation, we first check if our array has only one element or no elements at all. If so, we simply return it as it is already sorted.

If our array contains more than one element, we select our pivot as the first element and create two new arrays: "lesser" and "greater". The "lesser" array will contain all elements less than or equal to our chosen pivot value, while the "greater" array will hold those greater than it.

We then recursively apply this process by calling our function on both sub-arrays and concatenating them together with our chosen pivot value placed between them.
